newsitem.title: FRANCE: Bank of France trims intervention rate to 3.35 pct. [CORRECTED 14:25 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Bank of France trims intervention rate to 3.35 pct. [CORRECTED 14:25 GMT]

text.p: The Bank of France trimmed a key interest rate on Thursday, lowering its intervention rate to 3.35 percent from 3.55 at a money market tender.

Economists had virtually ruled out a cut on the day that the Bank's monetary policy council held its first meeting after the summer break, but the cut was preceded by a reduction in the German repo rate to 3.0 from 3.30 percent by the Bundesbank.
The Bank left the five-to-10 day rate, which is considered less important at the moment, unchanged at 4.75 percent (corrects from 4.90 percent).
The intervention rate was last cut -- from 3.60 percent -- on July 4, 1996.
The Bank of France drained 3.9 billion francs ($766.2 million) at its tender to allocate funds for injection into the money market on Friday.
It accepted bids for 44.2 billion francs in new liquidity, 3.9 billion less than the 48.1 billion leaving the market on Friday when the previous pact expires. The new pact expires on August 30.
